comments.commentBody:
I'm sure it had nothing to do w/ his occasional criticism of Obama.
I'm sure that the timing as NBC's uber boss takes power in the administration was a coincidence.
OC I'm also sure that when Loughner targeted Rep. Giffords back in 2007 he knew what Palin would do in 2008.

Gentlemen:
(Altho I hesitate to use this salutation in reference to NBC/MSNBC.) I shall be one fewer viewer of MSNBC.

Sure the one night I don't watch his show this happens. It's probably my fault. Actually I have noticed he has been off a lot more in the last two years. Much of that was because of his parents. Could it be that he is worn out?

I do think they dhould have given me more notice that this change was coming to MY LIFE.

I do hope Comcast understands the profit in having one network for liberals.

Its so unbelievable that this is happening. Keiths contribution to the debate is necessary in this political climate and to silence him is a sad day for journalism and our so called free speech! Who's next, Rachel? I hope Keith finds his way back to all of us soon. He will be missed but hopefully not for long.

If CNN has any brains, it would immediately sign Mr. Olbermann in any capacity possible, whether on CNN radio or for cnn.com, with an understanding that Mr. Olbermann would get his own prime-time show on CNN as soon as the non-compete clause with NBC expires.

This stinks to high heaven. And raises serious concerns about where progressive voices can find safe harbor as big media consolidates. Rachel Madow seemed a bit freaked out by it last night on Real Time. It will be interesting to see how she and the other remaining progressive show host on MSNBC react in the days ahead.

Yeah Right! So what will be left? !984 finally arrives in 2011.
Let's establish a Ministry of Truth to get the real story.
Time to cancel my Comcast subscription. Most of the channels Comcast provides are garbage. MSNBC is an exception and I've enjoyed Olbermann since he was a sports broadcaster in Los Angeles.
Restrictions on what can be said about the decision. Who are they kidding? It smacks of a firing and most everyone will reach that conclusion
Rumor has it that Sarah Palin will now replace Olbermann.Welcome to Tea Party USA.
Phil Griffin took Keith into a room and only Phil came out.
COMCAST is the American version of NEWSCORP. We will be drowning in the Republican financed FOX type propaganda. More hate pushers by dolts to dolts. America can not be saved as of this date.
By being able to contribute to "any forum on the Internet," one might expect to see Mr. Olbermann as a frequent contributor to The Huffington Post. That would be a welcomed sight.
Keith had the best real political news show on TV.  Hate to see it go.

Keith Olbermann WAS MSNBC. HE single-handedly made MSNBC into a real competitive network......and this is how NBC repays him. Further, they have committed him to silence. My, my, what are they afraid of!

I still cannot believe that MSNBC did this!

KEITH was one of the few voices telling the truth about what is really going on in politics today. His liberal voice cannot not and must not be stilled.

All "KEITH LOYALISTS" should believe that HE will be back, because HE will......and bigger and better than ever!

Thanks, Keith! YOU are the best!

It took a day but the PR people finally put out a cover story. It doesn't hold much water but it's the best they could do. The abruptness of the termination undercuts any credibility on NBC's part. We knew about Conan for months. This appears just as arbitrary as his suspension.

How in the world is this a free speech issue? A private company has every right to determine the tone and message of its broadcasts. If NBC or Comcast decided KO was becoming too incendiary and partisan for a "news" program, they are free to let him go. Is a law professor from Nebraska the best the Times can do to posit this silly argument? The left continues to recklessly abuse the first amendment to push their agenda (e.g. using the the AZ tragedy to try to muzzle conservative political rhetoric that was proven to be entirely unrelated to the shootings). Besides, Lawrence O'Donnell who is taking Olbermann's spot is just as partisan, perhaps worse, psychotic: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NsjuOcGATu0

Let me get in before the more vocal haters get in. I'll certainly miss Mr. Olberman's nightly visits into my home. His refreshing erudite commentary, and wordplay were a breath of fresh air compared to many other commentators who seem to try to "dumb it down" to the lowest common denominator.

I will have to wait for the real reasons as to his leaving, there are plenty of rumors flying. I'll just hope for the best in that his hiatus from the airwaves is brief.

For the last six months or so I have been unable to watch "Count Down" because the tone had become too intensely angry. Even to the point that perhaps the name, for desciptive honesty,  should have been changed to (dare I say it) "Shoot Down".  Having said that, I think that if Comcast has the power to "shake down" the government and impose its own agenda on news programming, it would be more precise, when Mr. O'Donnell takes over, to rename the show "Shake Down".
i feel like I've lost my best friend. I will follow him wherever he goes. The best liberal mind to come along in years. Hurry back to the air waves Keith. This country needs you now!

I see the Second Amendment is more important than the First Amendment - at least with corporate America and Republicans. Hopefully KO will get a good job where he will be able to continue to get out the word on important stories. We need more responsible voices like his.

This is a huge loss to those of us who appreciate a counterpoint to the ad nauseum dim-witted propoganda that passes for intelligent commentary (Fox cable, anyone) in the television news industry.  When in doubt, follow the money.  No one will convince me that the Comcast/NBC merger didn't play a significant role in Mr. Olbermann's departure.  I, for one, will enormously miss his wit and willingness to stand by his own words and look forward to his eventual return in whatever venue he chooses most appropriate, whether in print, radio or television.

First corporations get control of elections and now the end of free speech. Good bye democracy.
And the right has the nerve to call Obama socialists.

Keith Olbermann saved my family's sanity in the darkest days of the Bush Administration, when the rest of the media were parroting White House press releases with little critical thinking. Along comes Keith, and suddenly a sane voice is on prime time! He really gave us hope that we could take our country back from corporatist neo-cons, who were both destroying the economy and taking us into two ruinous wars under false pretenses. I was always amazed at the lack of questioning by both the Times and Congress. But again, there was Keith. And millions of people like me - critical, questioning thinkers - tuned in. Yes, it had its tongue-in-cheek schlocky element, but even that was welcomed. I hope we're not too long without his voice, and may he do even better in his next endeavor. I for one will follow him to the next network or radio show.

May the Giffords of the world get their just desserts in the meantime.
I wonder if the author will ask Mr. Griffin how close he came to firing Joe Starbucks when he made political contributions that ran afoul of network policies.
